Largest Animal in the World - Check Some Fascinating Facts

Last updated on Nov 2, 2023 
 Download as PDF




In the vast tapestry of our planet's wildlife, a select few creatures loom large, quite literally, as the giants of the animal kingdom. While our world is teeming with diverse life forms, the quest to identify the largest animal in the world sparks curiosity and wonder. As we embark on this journey to explore these colossal inhabitants, we delve into the mysteries of our oceans and the magnificence of land-dwelling leviathans, unearthing the awe-inspiring facts about the largest and second-largest animals on Earth. From the ocean's depths to the world's most captivating landscapes, we encounter the titans of the natural world. So, which is the largest animal in the world, and what makes it truly exceptional? Let's begin our voyage of discovery.

Explore more static GK topics now!



Which is the Largest Animal in the World?

The largest animal in the world is the blue whale. Blue whales can grow up to 100 feet long and weigh up to 200 tons. They are found in all of the world's oceans, but they are most common in the Southern Ocean.

 

Blue whales are filter feeders, meaning that they eat small organisms called krill. They can eat up to 4 tons of krill per day!

Blue whales are also the loudest animals in the world. Their calls can be heard up to 1,600 kilometers away.

Blue whales are amazing creatures, and they play an important role in the marine ecosystem. They are also a popular tourist attraction, and many people travel from all over the world to see these magnificent animals.

Interesting Facts About Blue Whale - Largest Animal in the World

Some fascinating facts about blue whales are -

Gargantuan Size: Blue whales are colossal creatures, with lengths ranging from 80 to 100 feet (24 to 30 meters). Some have even been reported to reach 108 feet (33 meters) in length. To put it in perspective, that's equivalent to three school buses lined up in a row.

Incredible Weight: These gentle giants weigh an average of 200,000 to 300,000 pounds (90,000 to 136,000 kilograms), or about 100 to 150 tons. Some can be as hefty as 441,000 pounds (200,000 kilograms), which is approximately the weight of 30 adult African bush elephants.

Massive Heart: Blue whales possess the largest heart in the animal kingdom, weighing around 400 pounds (180 kilograms). This heart is as heavy as a gorilla and roughly the size of a bumper car. During dives, their heart may beat as slowly as twice per minute.

Enormous Tongue: A blue whale's tongue alone can weigh as much as an elephant.

Biggest Babies: Blue whale calves are the largest babies on Earth, emerging at around 8,800 pounds (4,000 kg) and a length of approximately 26 feet (8 meters). They gain 200 pounds (90 kg) per day and experience one of the fastest growth rates in the animal kingdom, growing several billion-fold from conception to weaning in 18 months.

Ear-Splitting Sound: Blue whales are the loudest animals on the planet. While a jet engine registers at 140 decibels, the call of a blue whale can reach 180. Their vocalizations of pulses, groans, and moans can travel up to 1,000 miles (1,600 kilometers) away.

Krill Feast: These colossal creatures primarily feed on krill. Their stomachs can hold 2,200 pounds (1,000 kilograms) of these tiny crustaceans at once, requiring nearly 9,000 pounds (4,000 kilograms) of krill daily during the summer feeding season.

Impressive Speed: Blue whales are capable of swimming at speeds of up to 20 mph (32 kph), although they typically travel more slowly, with a cruising speed of 5 mph (8 kph).

Long Lifespan: Blue whales are among the longest-lived animals on Earth, with an average lifespan estimated to be around 80 to 90 years. Some have been known to live up to 100 years. Scientists can estimate their age by counting wax layers in their ears.

Drastic Population Decline: Blue whales faced a significant decline in population due to whaling in the 20th century. From 1904 to 1967, more than 350,000 blue whales were hunted in the Southern Hemisphere. In 1931, a staggering 29,000 blue whales were killed in a single season. Fortunately, they received worldwide protection in 1967.

Uncertain Future: Although commercial whaling is no longer a major threat, blue whales still face challenges such as ship strikes and the impacts of climate change. The species remains endangered, with roughly 10,000 to 25,000 individuals left in total. Conservation efforts are ongoing to ensure the survival of these magnificent creatures.

Second Largest Animal in the World

The fin whale (Balaenoptera physalus, Linnaeus, 1758) is the second largest animal in the world, after the blue whale. It is a filter-feeding cetacean that can grow up to 25 meters in length and weigh up to 70 tons. Fin whales are found in all of the world's oceans, but they prefer deep waters. They are typically solitary animals, but they can sometimes be seen in small groups. Fin whales migrate long distances each year, following their food supply of krill and other small organisms.

Fin whales are an important part of the marine ecosystem. They help to control populations of krill and other plankton, and they also provide food for other animals, such as sharks and killer whales.

Fun facts about fin whales


Fin whales are the fastest of all baleen whales, reaching speeds of up to 35 kilometers per hour.

Fin whales have a unique two-tone colouration, with a dark gray back and a lighter gray belly.

Fin whales have a lifespan of up to 90 years.

Fin whales are highly vocal animals, and their calls can be heard up to 1,600 kilometers away.


Fin whales are facing a number of threats, including pollution, overfishing, and climate change. However, there are a number of organizations working to protect fin whales and other marine life.

What can you do to help fin whales?


Reduce your plastic consumption. Plastic pollution is a major threat to marine life.

Support sustainable fishing practices. Overfishing can deplete food sources for fin whales and other marine animals.

Get involved in ocean conservation efforts. There are many organizations working to protect our oceans and the creatures that live in them.


By taking these steps, we can help to ensure that fin whales and other marine life continue to thrive for generations to come.

FAQs on Largest Animal in the World
What is the largest animal in the world?
The largest animal in the world is the blue whale, known for its enormous size and weight.

How big can blue whales grow?
Blue whales can reach lengths of up to 100 feet and weigh as much as 200 tons.

What is the second largest animal in the world?
The second largest animal in the world is the fin whale, following closely behind the blue whale in size.

How do blue whales feed?
Blue whales are filter feeders and primarily consume tiny organisms called krill.

Why are blue whales significant in the marine ecosystem?
Blue whales play a crucial role in controlling krill populations and provide food for other marine creatures. Their conservation is essential for a balanced marine ecosystem.

</h1>
<div _ngcontent-sc119 class="main-item__enrolled"><span _ngcontent-sc119 class="enrolled__time"><svg _ngcontent-sc119 width="11" height="11"><use _ngcontent-sc119 xlink:href="#timer"></use></svg>Last updated on Nov 2, 2023 </span></div>

</target-page-header><div _ngcontent-sc167 class="wrapper-custom"><div _ngcontent-sc167 class="sidebar-grid"><div _ngcontent-sc167 class="sidebar-content__left"><div _ngcontent-sc167 class="wrapper"><div _ngcontent-sc167 class="card"><div _ngcontent-sc167 id="target-content"><target-page-content _ngcontent-sc167><div id="exam-info-container" class="exam-info-container"><div id="target-content-html" class="card lms-custom-style ui-js-external-links"><p>In the vast tapestry of our planet's wildlife, a select few creatures loom large, quite literally, as the giants of the animal kingdom. While our world is teeming with diverse life forms, the quest to identify the largest animal in the world sparks curiosity and wonder. As we embark on this journey to explore these colossal inhabitants, we delve into the mysteries of our oceans and the magnificence of land-dwelling leviathans, unearthing the awe-inspiring facts about the largest and second-largest animals on Earth. From the ocean's depths to the world's most captivating landscapes, we encounter the titans of the natural world. So, which is the largest animal in the world, and what makes it truly exceptional? Let's begin our voyage of discovery.</p>

<p>Explore more <a href="https://testbook.com/static-gk" target="_blank">static GK</a> topics now!</p>
</div>
</div>
</target-page-content></div>
<div _ngcontent-sc167 id="target-content"><target-page-content _ngcontent-sc167><div id="exam-info-container" class="exam-info-container"><div id="target-content-html" class="card lms-custom-style ui-js-external-links"><h2>Which is the Largest Animal in the World?</h2>

<p><strong>The largest animal in the world is the blue whale.</strong> Blue whales can grow up to 100 feet long and weigh up to 200 tons. They are found in all of the world's oceans, but they are most common in the Southern Ocean.</p>

<p><img src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=https://cdn.testbook.com/1698759080655-Blue%20whale.jpg/1698759081.jpeg" alt="Largest Animal in the World" width="1200" height="630"> </p>

<p>Blue whales are filter feeders, meaning that they eat small organisms called krill. They can eat up to 4 tons of krill per day!</p>

<p>Blue whales are also the loudest animals in the world. Their calls can be heard up to 1,600 kilometers away.</p>

<p>Blue whales are amazing creatures, and they play an important role in the marine ecosystem. They are also a popular tourist attraction, and many people travel from all over the world to see these magnificent animals.</p>
</div>
</div>

<div _ngcontent-sc167 id="target-content"><target-page-content _ngcontent-sc167><div id="exam-info-container" class="exam-info-container"><div id="target-content-html" class="card lms-custom-style ui-js-external-links"><h2>Interesting Facts About Blue Whale - Largest Animal in the World</h2>

<p>Some fascinating facts about blue whales are -</p>

<p><strong>Gargantuan Size:</strong> Blue whales are colossal creatures, with lengths ranging from 80 to 100 feet (24 to 30 meters). Some have even been reported to reach 108 feet (33 meters) in length. To put it in perspective, that's equivalent to three school buses lined up in a row.</p>

<p><strong>Incredible Weight:</strong> These gentle giants weigh an average of 200,000 to 300,000 pounds (90,000 to 136,000 kilograms), or about 100 to 150 tons. Some can be as hefty as 441,000 pounds (200,000 kilograms), which is approximately the weight of 30 adult African bush elephants.</p>

<p><strong>Massive Heart: </strong>Blue whales possess the largest heart in the animal kingdom, weighing around 400 pounds (180 kilograms). This heart is as heavy as a gorilla and roughly the size of a bumper car. During dives, their heart may beat as slowly as twice per minute.</p>

<p><strong>Enormous Tongue: </strong>A blue whale's tongue alone can weigh as much as an elephant.</p>

<p><strong>Biggest Babies: </strong>Blue whale calves are the largest babies on Earth, emerging at around 8,800 pounds (4,000 kg) and a length of approximately 26 feet (8 meters). They gain 200 pounds (90 kg) per day and experience one of the fastest growth rates in the animal kingdom, growing several billion-fold from conception to weaning in 18 months.</p>

<p><strong>Ear-Splitting Sound: </strong>Blue whales are the loudest animals on the planet. While a jet engine registers at 140 decibels, the call of a blue whale can reach 180. Their vocalizations of pulses, groans, and moans can travel up to 1,000 miles (1,600 kilometers) away.</p>

<p><strong>Krill Feast:</strong> These colossal creatures primarily feed on krill. Their stomachs can hold 2,200 pounds (1,000 kilograms) of these tiny crustaceans at once, requiring nearly 9,000 pounds (4,000 kilograms) of krill daily during the summer feeding season.</p>

<p><strong>Impressive Speed: </strong>Blue whales are capable of swimming at speeds of up to 20 mph (32 kph), although they typically travel more slowly, with a cruising speed of 5 mph (8 kph).</p>

<p><strong>Long Lifespan:</strong> Blue whales are among the longest-lived animals on Earth, with an average lifespan estimated to be around 80 to 90 years. Some have been known to live up to 100 years. Scientists can estimate their age by counting wax layers in their ears.</p>

<p><strong>Drastic Population Decline: </strong>Blue whales faced a significant decline in population due to whaling in the 20th century. From 1904 to 1967, more than 350,000 blue whales were hunted in the Southern Hemisphere. In 1931, a staggering 29,000 blue whales were killed in a single season. Fortunately, they received worldwide protection in 1967.</p>

<p><strong>Uncertain Future: </strong>Although commercial whaling is no longer a major threat, blue whales still face challenges such as ship strikes and the impacts of climate change. The species remains endangered, with roughly 10,000 to 25,000 individuals left in total. Conservation efforts are ongoing to ensure the survival of these magnificent creatures.</p>
</div>
</div>
</target-page-content></div>

</horizontal-pass-banner><div _ngcontent-sc167 id="target-content"><target-page-content _ngcontent-sc167><div id="exam-info-container" class="exam-info-container"><div id="target-content-html" class="card lms-custom-style ui-js-external-links"><h2>Second Largest Animal in the World</h2>

<p>The fin whale (Balaenoptera physalus, Linnaeus, 1758) is the second largest animal in the world, after the blue whale. It is a filter-feeding cetacean that can grow up to 25 meters in length and weigh up to 70 tons. Fin whales are found in all of the world's oceans, but they prefer deep waters. They are typically solitary animals, but they can sometimes be seen in small groups. Fin whales migrate long distances each year, following their food supply of krill and other small organisms.</p>

<p>Fin whales are an important part of the marine ecosystem. They help to control populations of krill and other plankton, and they also provide food for other animals, such as sharks and killer whales.</p>

<h3>Fun facts about fin whales</h3>

<ul>
<li>Fin whales are the fastest of all baleen whales, reaching speeds of up to 35 kilometers per hour.</li>

<li>Fin whales have a unique two-tone colouration, with a dark gray back and a lighter gray belly.</li>

<li>Fin whales have a lifespan of up to 90 years.</li>

<li>Fin whales are highly vocal animals, and their calls can be heard up to 1,600 kilometers away.</li>

</ul>
<p>Fin whales are facing a number of threats, including pollution, overfishing, and climate change. However, there are a number of organizations working to protect fin whales and other marine life.</p>

<h3>What can you do to help fin whales?</h3>

<ul>
<li>Reduce your plastic consumption. Plastic pollution is a major threat to marine life.</li>

<li>Support sustainable fishing practices. Overfishing can deplete food sources for fin whales and other marine animals.</li>

<li>Get involved in ocean conservation efforts. There are many organizations working to protect our oceans and the creatures that live in them.</li>

</ul>
<p>By taking these steps, we can help to ensure that fin whales and other marine life continue to thrive for generations to come.</p>

To know more about other important GK topics, download our <a href="https://link.testbook.com/ygVdC9p6Vyb" target="_blank">Testbook app</a> today and make your way easy to learn.</p>
</div>
